title: Lets be real here, Azir and Khalista are a huge fuck you to melee champs.
body:
Look I don't know how these characters create a healthy environment in league. These champs are jam packed with massive amounts of utility on top of mobility and the only trade off they have is being squishy which pretty much every dps champion is. I don't see what their real trade-offs are when they bring so much to a team. While I do like the fact that these champs make players want to be more creative with team-comps I don't see how these champions encourage diversity. Azir and Khalista force you into playing champs that counter them specifically. 

While I do find these champs to be very creative with interesting and I don't see how they fit into the League environment. These champs remind me of Lee Sin in how they have everything you want in a champion with arbitrary trade-offs. I feel like these champions existing crowds out the other guys in League who are lagging behind. We talk about increasing diversity but how does a champ like Zac survive when Azir can just Ult and say fuck you to Zac, we can even go further and ask ourselves how does Olaf deal with Khalista when his only form of engage is Axe spam. I honestly don't know how one deals with these champs beside just outright catching them out of position and dunking on them which is every bodies weakness. Maybe someone can give me another side to this and explain to me how these champions can work in a healthy way that adds more depth to the game cause it just looks like powercreep to me.

Azir is incredibly vulnerable to stuns, snares, fears, and other CCs. TF is a pain in the ass to lane against, Ziggs and Lux can easily outpoke him and Lux even brings a shield, Xerath and Syndra can stun him and generally poke him from far away. To beat him, you just have to be quick on your feet and make sure you're aware of your positioning because he can punish you if you're out of position.

He and Kalista are both pretty squishy to make up for their mobility, but while Kalista can kite for days, Azir can dash once, making him similar to such OP champions as Graves, Lucian, and Sejuani.

> Azir can just Ult and say fuck you to Zac

This wouldn't be the first time someone's ult counteracts someone else's. Viktor can just ult and say fuck you to Kat. And Azir's ult is utility, not damage. 300 + 60% AP at level 16? Even Orianna at least has 300 + 70% AP. Unless you're right on top of Azir, it likely won't deal damage to you anyway. Kalista's ult is 100% pure utility. It deals no damage AT ALL.

Thing about azir is stupid high range and turrets that can zone you out as a melee. Coupled with mobility and disengage.

The thing is, if you're getting poked down you will lose. That's standard for any midlaner. If you let Xerath or Lux poke you down from far away, you will lose. The correct response, counterintuitively, is to play somewhat aggressively and poke back. If you're afraid to go in, he has already won, because he sucks at close range. Honestly. As Azir, you do not want someone to be right on top of you, because to deal any damage, you have to stop moving and do your AA animation..

Which melee do you play in midlane who lacks a gap-closer?

I don't play any with a 850 range gapcloser. Anyways I'm not complaining so much as pointing out there's a legitimate reason many melee champions hate playing against him. Long range turrets that are much better at zoning you if you have to walk into the wave.

My point was that this is true with literally every champion who can zone you from long range. Okay, Xerath and Lux don't have turrets. Lux can still zone you out by hovering an E over your minions as you're coming in to last hit. Xerath can fire his piercing skillshot, or his AOE slow if you're behind minions, or his stun when you're not behind minions. Or let's compare to Zyra, or Heimer. They both have similar "turrets", though Heimer's don't expire like Zyra's do, and Zyra and Heimer don't even have to stand still to command an attack.

Azir is just a slight twist on Orianna, Zyra, and Lux. His zones are temporary, but hit very hard if you stay inside them. As a result, he must either summon them on top of where you will be, or move them with a Q that has a several-second cooldown and which makes it hard for him to then dash out if he miscalculates (WQE is his best escape mechanism).

Zoning champions are designed to make it hard to last-hit, and to control zones of the lane. They are at their strongest when you're at range, or in their zones of control, and they win if you are afraid to go in. Their drawback is that every single one is very very squishy, and they all push the lane like crazy, making it easy for junglers to gank. They're also quite susceptible to gap-closers (why do you think assassins destroy Lux and Azir?)
